list_definition.definition: able to be washed without being damaged

list_ex_of_english: The term first originated in the late nineteenth century to describe at-home garments designed for maximum practicality and usually made from washable fabrics.
In 2012 these are the available colors: black, green, blue-black, blue washable, turquoise, red and violet.
Each sleeping bag is equipped with a liner, which is detachable, washable, and can be renewed separately.
A sink with a good supply of water, adequate electrical fittings, a waterproof floor and washable walls and ceiling must also be provided.
Teaching materials can be pre-printed on plastic sheets, upon which the educator can directly write using a non-permanent, washable color marking pen.
The blue uniform supplied has to be of a strong, but washable material.
The printed fabric is dipped in water to set the ink after the inkjet ink dries, making it washable.
The material is made from polymer, and produces washable, re-usable clothing.
